) IRC
, Allocation of Income and Deductions Among Taxpayers, provides (

) that: Background In any case of two or more organizations, trades, or businesses (whether or not corporated, whether or not organized in the United States, and whether or not affiliated) owned or controlled directly or indirectly by the same interests, the Secretary may distribute, apportion, or allocate gross income, deductions, credits, allowances between or among such organizations, trades, or businesses, if he de- termines that such distribution, apportionment, or allocation is necessary in order prevent evasion of taxes or clearly to reﬂect the income of any of such organiza- tions, trades, or businesses. In the case of any transfer (or license) of intangible property (within the meaning of section

)), the income with respect to transfer or license shall be commensurate with the income attributable to the gible. For purposes of this section, the Secretary shall require the valuation of transfers of intangible property (including intangible property transferred with other property or services) on an aggregate basis or the valuation of such a transfer on the basis of the realistic alternatives to such a transfer, if the Secretary that such basis is the most reliable means of valuation of such transfers. Program Goals: The goal of this program is to provide guidance to examiners making IRC 482 primary and correlative adjustments.

In any case of two or more organizations, trades, or businesses (whether or not in- corporated, whether or not organized in the United States, and whether or not affiliated) owned or controlled directly or indirectly by the same interests, the Secretary may distribute, apportion, or allocate gross income, deductions, credits, allowances between or among such organizations, trades, or businesses, if he de- termines that such distribution, apportionment, or allocation is necessary in order prevent evasion of taxes or clearly to reﬂect the income of any of such organiza- tions, trades, or businesses. In the case of any transfer (or license) of intangible property (within the meaning of section 367(d)(4)), the income with respect to such transfer or license shall be commensurate with the income attributable to the intan- gible. For purposes of this section, the Secretary shall require the valuation of transfers of intangible property (including intangible property transferred with other property or services) on an aggregate basis or the valuation of such a transfer on the basis of the realistic alternatives to such a transfer, if the Secretary determines that such basis is the most reliable means of valuation of such transfers.

(1) The objective of this IRM is to provide guidance on applicable substantive rules for examiners working cases under IRC 482 involving the allocation of Objectives and income and deductions among taxpayers. of Income and Deductions Under IRC 482

Term Deﬁnition Citation Arm’s Length The standard to be applied Treas. Reg. 1.482- Standard in every case is that of a 1(b) taxpayer dealing at arm’s length with an uncontrolled taxpayer. A controlled transaction meets the arm’s length standard if the results of the transaction are consistent with the results that would have been realized if uncon- trolled taxpayers engaged in the same transaction under the same circum- stances (arm’s length result). Collateral Adjust- Adjustment of related tax Treas. Reg. 1.482- ment items, as provided for by 1(g) regulations, reﬂecting impli- cations of an allocation under IRC 482, including correlative allocations, con- forming adjustments, and setoffs. Controlled A taxpayer under common Treas. Reg. 1.482- Taxpayer ownership or common 1(i)(5) control with another. Control can be direct or indirect, need not be legally enforceable, and depends on the facts and circum- stances. Primary Allocation The initial allocation under Treas. Reg. IRC 482. 1.482-1(g)(2)(i)
The purpose of IRC
is to ensure taxpayers clearly reﬂect income attribut- able to controlled transactions and to prevent avoidance of taxes regarding such transactions. IRC

places a controlled taxpayer on a tax parity with an uncontrolled taxpayer in determining true taxable income. Transactions between controlled taxpayers will be subject to special scrutiny to ascertain whether common control is being used to reduce, avoid or escape taxes. In determining the true taxable income of a controlled taxpayer, the Service is not restricted to the case of improper accounting, to the case of a fraudulent or sham transaction or to the case of a device designed to reduce or avoid tax by shifting or distorting income, deductions, credits, or allowances. The authority to determine true taxable income extends to any case in which, either by inad- vertence or design, the taxable income of a controlled taxpayer does not reﬂect an arm’s length result as with an uncontrolled taxpayer.
(11-19-2019) Overview of IRC 482 Allocation of Income and Deductions Taxpayers
) Transactions between controlled taxpayers which may involve an IRC

issue include (but are not limited to) the following: a. One entity makes a loan or advance to another entity and charges no interest or charges an interest rate which is not arm’s length (including excessive rate). b. One entity performs services for another entity without charge or at a charge which does not reﬂect an arm’s length result. c. One entity leases property to another entity without charge or at a that is not an arm’s length result. d. One entity sells tangible or intangible property to another entity charge or at a sales price that is not an arm’s length result. e. One entity licenses intangible property to another entity for no royalty or a fee that is not an arm’s length result. f. One entity enters into a Treas. Reg.

cost sharing arrangement (CSA) with another entity to share costs to develop intangibles, but all costs are not appropriately shared. g. One entity contributes a valuable platform including intangibles upon entering into, or subsequent to entering into, a Treas. Reg.
to be used and further developed by the parties in the arrangement changes its participation in a CSA) without receiving an arm’s length payment from the other entit(ies). (

) The initial allocation, which ordinarily increases the income of one or more members of the controlled group, is referred to as the “primary allocation” and Correlative the “primary adjustment” and the corresponding decrease of the other member(s) is the “correlative allocation” or “correlative adjustment.” (
) Issue teams should review the advance notiﬁcation procedures under IRM
, Mutual Agreement Procedures and Report Guidelines, regarding primary and correlative adjustments, whenever an IRC
adjustment is ticipated. (
) Primary adjustments should be shared with the team coordinator as soon they are known. These adjustments may affect other items within the Adjustment er’s tax return. (
) The concurrent examination of the income tax return(s) of the correlative justment taxpayer(s) should ordinarily be made when a primary adjustment Adjustment examination is underway. (

Transactions between controlled taxpayers which may involve an IRC 482 issue include (but are not limited to) the following:

a. One entity makes a loan or advance to another entity and charges no interest or charges an interest rate which is not arm’s length (including excessive rate). b. One entity performs services for another entity without charge or at a charge which does not reﬂect an arm’s length result. c. One entity leases property to another entity without charge or at a that is not an arm’s length result. d. One entity sells tangible or intangible property to another entity without charge or at a sales price that is not an arm’s length result. e. One entity licenses intangible property to another entity for no royalty fee or a fee that is not an arm’s length result. f. One entity enters into a Treas. Reg.

cost sharing arrangement (CSA) with another entity to share costs to develop intangibles, but all costs are not appropriately shared. g. One entity contributes a valuable platform including intangibles upon entering into, or subsequent to entering into, a Treas. Reg.
CSA to be used and further developed by the parties in the arrangement (or changes its participation in a CSA) without receiving an arm’s length payment from the other entit(ies).

) The correlative adjustment should not be made until the primary adjustment has been made. Per Treas. Reg.

)(iii), the primary adjustment will not be considered to have been made and, accordingly, a correlative adjust- ment is not required to be made until the date of a ﬁnal determination on the primary adjustment under IRC
For this purpose, a ﬁnal determination includes:

includes: a. Assessment of the tax following execution by the taxpayer of Form Waiver of Restrictions on Assessment and Collection of Deﬁciency in and Acceptance of Overassessment, with respect to such adjustment. b. Acceptance of a Form

-AD, (Offer of Waiver of Restrictions on As- sessment and Collection of Deﬁciency in Tax and Assessment of Overassessment). c. Payment of the deﬁciency. d. Stipulation in the Tax Court of the United States. e. Final determination of tax liability by offer-in-compromise, closing agreement, or ﬁnal resolution (determined under the principles of IRC
) of a judicial proceeding. To provide uniform treatment of all IRC

cases, agreed or unagreed, reports on the primary adjustment taxpayer and the correlative adjustment taxpayer should be prepared concurrently, kept together and transmitted to next function, (e.g., Case Processing, Technical Services, or Office of In cases with no current tax effect as a result of a correlative adjustment foreign entity, loss entity, etc.), place a statement in the correlative taxpayer’s audit report to the effect that the correlative adjustments are deemed to have been made when and if: a. The adjustments are agreed to and assessment has been made; or b. The deﬁciency has been paid and will be given effect to when the cor- relative adjustment produces a current tax effect. It is important that this statement be included in all reports prepared for the taxpayer(s) to which the correlative adjustments apply so the subsequent issue team does not miss the effect of these adjustments in the event of a subsequent examination or carryback of losses or credits or other events which do have a tax effect.
